comments.commentBody:
Bill, compare your calculation against the Congressional salary of $174,000 per year (plus generous health insurance, pension, travel allowance, etc.) and you see why minimum wage, among other things, is not a priority for the Congress. They may not be in the top 1%, but the members of Congress are near the top. Minimum wage has zero effect on their lives.

Combine that with the influence (by means of campaign contributions) of those who have a vested interest in keeping the minimum wage as minimum as possible, you see why minimum wage is stuck at where it is. doesn't care to do anything about the minimum wage.
In a day?  Isn't it more like in an hour?

$7.25/hr * 2000 hrs/yr = $14,500/yr
Subtract 6.2% for FICA = 0.938 x $14,500 = $13,601 take home before taxes

Compare $13,601 to the HHS poverty threshold values for 2012:
http://aspe.hhs.gov/poverty/12poverty.shtml

Isn't it wonderful to work 40 hours a week to be poor?

Particularly when the 1% make as much in a day as you do in a year and cry poverty when asked to pay their taxes.
Let me add that I'd say yes if we implement a huge export tax and use that money to subsidize the development of solar and wind power, including manufacturing facilities) in the US.
I'm guessing that the Woody Woodpecker was a "drummer" in that he used his beak to make a helluva racket all the time. Or maybe I'm completely off.

There have been multiple instances within the past year or so of police officer's children have been killed with the officer's weapon (often not specified in the article whether it was a duty or personal weapon). A gun is not some magical force that will protect every one in the home and ensure that no harm comes to them. Police officers are certainly not infallible. If my child were for some reason going to a police officer's house to play, I would want to check, what precautions are taken, because I would know that is a house with weapons.

Not just you Ellen, but several people have brought up the idea of offending the other person. I get that, and I would try to ask in as inoffensive a way as possible. However, possibly offending someone is a small price to pay for keeping my child safe.
Five, that sounds like you took it from the "Car Talk" credits.

I remember Tryon in Texas John Slaughter and enjoyed both the book and movie version of 'The Other.'

In Harm's Way is also one of my favorite Wayne movies (and the title is from one of my favorite quotes). Wayne and Patricia Neal make a perfect couple.
LOL Leapy - real store, though.

16A: TRYON

From Wikipedia (Martin’s source of last resort - welcome back, Martin):
Tom Tryon (January 14, 1926 – September 4, 1991) was an American film and television actor, best known for playing the title role in the film The Cardinal (1963) and the Walt Disney television character Texas John Slaughter (1958–1961). He later became a writer and authored several science fiction, horror and mystery novels.

From me:
I remember him in the movie In Harm’s Way (1965), my favorite later John Wayne movie and the last movie I saw before exiting the Air Force. He was probably better known and achieved greater success as an author. He died at the age of 65 from cancer.

The odds are not good but it would make a good fight. Much better than worrying about tax breaks for those who worry about such things.

Kevin, I know you know that there is no free market. I join you and add that the lack of free and open competition is one of the problems that is having a negative effect on our economy. In "The Rise and Decline of Nations", published in 1982, Mancur Olson, a distinguished economist, explains how stable, affluent societies get in trouble. In Olson’s view, successful countries breed interest groups that become more and more powerful with time. The groups win government favors, in the form of new laws or friendly regulators that benefit them at everyone else’s expense. Not only do they grab a larger piece of the economic pie, but they stop the pie from growing as much as it could. Professor Olson’s thesis on the power of moneyed special interest and its bad effect on the economy has been supported many times over since his study. For example, look at what Google could do with about $25 million in lobbying to escape anti-trust enforcement.

In my two decades of trying to introduce superconducting Maglev, it has been very frustrating to try and overcome the power of other transport interests and prove that this system is faster, cheaper, and much more energy efficient than steel-wheeled rail systems.

In "Wealth and Democracy." Kevin Phillips points out that there is a feedback in economic distribution because as the rich get richer, they use their wealth to get more power. They then use their power to get more wealth and so on. There seems to be a tipping point where this process becomes impossible to reverse. When inequality becomes bad enough, the country suffers. This process has been going on for centuries. Chrystia Freeland used 14th century Venice to illustrate this process in a recent article, but history is replete with other examples. It appears that at some point the process becomes impossible to reverse.

According to Phillips, the great success of America has been that before the tipping point was reached, something has always happened that reversed the flow of money upwards, e.g. the rise of unions, FDR's reforms.

Nice editorial. What are the odds that Congress, dominated by Republican Tea Party  obstructionists, will do anything? Most of them oppose the entire concept of a minimum wage and would love to see the minimum wage abolished. Every person for himself. Let the free market dictate wages. Good grief!!
He was NEVER "near death," he was at a stage where about half eventually survive and half eventually don't, and that's if you believe him and his doctors.
...except when it doesn't.
How can you call Armstrong a good man as he deliberately went out of his way trying to destroy careers of those who accused him of doping.
Armstrong is "a hero's hero to most of the world"?  That is based on, what, a sample set of...one?  He's also a lying, vindictive, slandering cheater to millions.
Give the man a break? He lied for years and has discredited his sport.
Perfectly said, Tom!

Rewrite your essay substituting banks or energy companies or any other "villain" & their nefarious deeds.  Still think it's OK?  Does Goldman Sachs get to keep the millions because everybody did it but they cheated better than the other banks?

Is there any connection between this news and Johann Bruyneel's testimony? Isn't LA going to be outed by his manager, Johann, anyway? LA needs to apologize to Greg LeMond, Tyler Hamilton, Floyd Landis, and the whole world. Otherwise, STEP OFF.

Yeah, jail for lying. Doin' hard time, breaking big rocks into little ones--over telling a fib. Listen pal, they all doped...they all doped...every guy clipped into his pedals doped during their whole cycling career.

The governing body only went after Lance, due to those 7 consecutive wins on the Tour. But they were all doping...and only an absolute fool would even attempt to deny it.

All Lance is really guilty of...is winning. The sport was/is so freaking corrupt. If some other guy, Joe Cyclist, had won those seven Tours, then--right now--it would not be Lance Armstrong on the hot seat, it would be Joe Cyclist.

I mean, get it?

Lance is no more criminal than you or I...heck, perhaps especially you. It take genuine ethics and intelligence to forge and individualistic path. The fabulous vast majority of average thinkers however, do what everybody else does.

If you'd have been a cyclist then, you'd have been doping too. And to imagine otherwise is nothing short of lying to yourself to the point of purely egotistical fantasy. And here's the worst part--you'd have doped, but just like all the rest of 'em--you wouldn't have won...you'd have done all that blood doping for no worthwhile reward at the end.

And that, my friend, would have you outraged and squealing on the winner. Which, of course, is just exactly how Lance was caught. Spiteful, petty, little black and white non-thinkers, jealous and vengeful--squealing like spoil brats to daddy...Lance did it.
Your irony is so subtly buried that many readers may miss your true intent - which is to point out that Armstrong is a self-serving creep.

Yeah, but get it in perspective pal. He didn't do anything that all of the other cyclists didn't do. They all doped. They all cheated.

Lance just happened to win.

And, now, here's the big bad devastating perspective. If you'd have been a cyclist? you'd have doped too. You're no different than they are.

You don't realize it, but when you point the finger at and bad mouth Lance, you are pointing the finger at and bad mouthing yourself. There exists nothing in your comments which would lead anyone to believe that your character is of any higher quality or more strength than any of the cyclists blood doping on those Tours.

Think about it...and don't stop thinking about it--until you finally realize that it's just plain 100% true.
When you say "Armstrong's charity efforts" you mean his lining of his own pockets and turning cancer into the family business?
Doping IS cheating!

Lance Armstrong uses charities to support his lifestyle and aggrandize his ego.

He has repeatedly misled on the matter of Livestrong and supporting cancer and cancer research.
The rest is DRUGS!
Strong will and determination do not beat cancer. I'm glad he surived his cancer, but please, cross that off his list of accomplishments.

Everything Lance does, it would seem, is always and only about Lance. He seems to fit the profile of a sociopath, posted, ironically enough, on the livestrong.com website.

http://www.livestrong.com/article/111043-description-sociopath/

I will take your bet. Not everyone doped. In fact the dopers were far fewer than you would likely believe.

Armstrong is a first order dirtbag.

Livestrong does not support cancer research. Their "Cancer awareness" has been exemplified by purchasing artwork, paying for travel and public relations people for Lance Armstrong and generally making Lance richer.

As a current cancer survivor and patient I find any suggestion that Livestrong benefits the cancer fight an offense.
